attributes.title: The impact of leadership on health and turnover-reworded hypotheses

q1.value: The effect of leadership on health and turnover

q4.value:
Psychopathic leaders will be high in both exploitative and abusive supervision (Dark Leadership)

Mental health problems and quit intentions will be high among employees whose supervisors have psychopathic traits or engage in exploitative or abusive supervision.

Machiavellianism will mitigate the impact of dark leadership such that subordinates high in Machiavellianism will report fewer quit intentions when their job satisfaction is high, even under psychopathic supervision.

Inconsistent ratings of a supervisor's psychopathy (e.g., the pps says s/he is not psychopathic, the coworker says s/he is) will lead to increased job satisfaction among subordinates high in Machiavellianism

IN general, employees high in the Dark Triad (i.e., psychopathic, Machiavellian, narcissistic) will see psychopathic leadership as better than employees low in any Dark Triad trait.

Closeness with a psychopathic leader will increase quit intentions and mental health problems among employees.

name.value: Different Feminisms: A nuanced examination of the links between feminist identity and self-objectification

sample.value: The sample size will be 300. We will stop collecting data once 300 responses have been collected.

analyses.value:
We will conduct an initial regression, with feminist identity (X) regressed on self-objectification (Y). 
We will conduct a multiple mediation analysis using Hayes PROCESS Macro, linking feminist identity (X) to self-objectification (Y) through Revelation (M1) and Synthesis (M2).

outliers.value: Participants will be removed from analyses if they fail to respond correctly to all three attention checks embedded in the Feminist Social Identity Scale.

dependent.value: The key dependent variable is self-objectification. Self-objectification will be assessed using Self-Objectification Scale (Talmon & Ginzburg, 2016) that was specifically designed to reflect self-objectification in terms of denial of subjectivity. Participants rate their level of agreement with 17 items that capture two distinct aspects of self-objectification: Invisibility (e.g., “When I say what I feel, other people pay no attention”) and lack of autonomy (“People act as if they can do with me as they please”). All items are scored on a Likert-scale ranging from 1 (hardly disagree) and 5 (strongly agree).

conditions.value: All participants will be exposed to the same set of questionnaires, so there is only one condition.

hypothesis.value: We hypothesize that Revelation and Synthesis will mediate the relation between feminist identity and self-objectification.

attributes.title: Prospect Theory Replication v2 (Public)
attributes.description: A multinational replication of the research design reported in Kahneman and Tversky's 1979 Econometrica paper "Prospect Theory: An Analysis of Decision under Risk".

summary.value:
This is a registration of the analysis plan for a multinational replication of the methods and and analysis described in Kahneman's and Tversky's 1979 Prospect Theory publication in Econometrica. Note that the pre-analysis plan is included in the "Files" section of the project. 

Though the date of this registration is after the study was completed, independent peer reviewers have confirmed that a substantially similar version of the pre-analysis plan had been posted prior to data collection and was replaced with another one after private details were discovered in that document.

attributes.title: The SPIRIT-Path Extension
attributes.description: Guidelines for Inclusion of Pathology-specific assessment and endpoints in Clinical Trial Protocols: The SPIRIT-Path Extension

summary.value:
[TITLE: Cellular and molecular pathology (‘Path’) input in clinical trials: A systematic literature review of guidance for trial protocol writers.]

This document attached is the prospective registration of the protocol for the systematic literature review, which is a review of the methodological strategies employed in the planning and executing of clinical trials that require cellular and molecular pathology input.
REVIEW OBJECTIVE:
This systematic review aims to review existing pathology-specific protocol guidance in clinical trials. Any best practice guidance obtained from this review will be retrieved to contribute to a summary checklist of pathology-specific recommendations and ultimately the development of the SPIRIT-Path guidelines, which would be an extension to the SPIRIT (Standard Protocol Items: Recommendations for Interventional Trials) statement.

attributes.title: An examination of the effects of a patient-designed-and-informed participant information sheet in comparison with a standard, researcher-designed information sheet on recruitment, retention and understanding: Protocol for a study-within-a-trial
attributes.description: Ireland - Background: This protocol describes a double-blind, randomised non-inferiority study-within-a-trial (SWAT), comparing the effects of a patient-designed-and-informed participant information sheet with a standard, researcher-designed participant information sheet on recruitment, retention, decision certainty, participant information sheet understanding and likeability. The SWAT is part of a larger trial that aims to evaluate the feasibility and preliminary efficacy of a cognitive occupation-based programme for people with MS (COB-MS) on cognitive and daily functioning for people with multiple sclerosis.  Methods: One-hundred and twenty people with multiple sclerosis will be randomly allocated to one of the two groups, where they will either receive a standard Participant Information Sheet or a patient-designed Participant Information Sheet. Recruitment and retention will be analysed, as well as decision certainty, likability and understanding.  Discussion: Results will provide recommendations for recruitment, consent and retention for future trials, as well as shed some light on the factors influencing the understanding and likeability of a trial’s participant information sheet. Recommendations will also be made regarding patient and public involvement in developing and/or aiding the development of participant information sheets.   Registration: SWAT 105: Available at: http://www.qub.ac.uk/sites/TheNorthernIrelandNetworkforTrialsMethodologyResearch/FileStore/Filetoupload,926069,en.pdf Keywords: Participation information, recruitment, retention, multiple sclerosis, public and patient involvement, PPI, SWAT

q1.value: An examination of the effects of a patient-designed-and-informed participant information sheet in comparison with a standard, researcher-designed information sheet on recruitment, retention and understanding: Protocol for a study-within-a-trial

q3.value: Background: This protocol describes a double-blind, randomised non-inferiority study-within-a-trial (SWAT), comparing the effects of a patient-designed-and-informed participant information sheet with a standard, researcher-designed participant information sheet on recruitment, retention, decision certainty, participant information sheet understanding and likeability. The SWAT is part of a larger trial that aims to evaluate the feasibility and preliminary efficacy of a cognitive occupation-based programme for people with MS (COB-MS) on cognitive and daily functioning for people with multiple sclerosis. Methods: One-hundred and twenty people with multiple sclerosis will be randomly allocated to one of the two groups, where they will either receive a standard Participant Information Sheet or a patient-designed Participant Information Sheet. Recruitment and retention will be analysed, as well as decision certainty, likability and understanding. Discussion: Results will provide recommendations for recruitment, consent and retention for future trials, as well as shed some light on the factors influencing the understanding and likeability of a trial’s participant information sheet. Recommendations will also be made regarding patient and public involvement in developing and/or aiding the development of participant information sheets.

q4.value: No hypotheses are made as the experimental comparison is exploratory in nature.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

question.value: The current SWAT is a double-blind, randomised non-inferiority trial comparing the effects of a patient-designed-and-informed PIS with a standard, researcher-designed PIS on recruitment (i.e. decision to consent), decision certainty, participant retention, PIS understanding, PIS likeability and decision to consent. The SWAT will be conducted in the context of a single-blind, cluster-randomised controlled feasibility and preliminary efficacy trial of the eight session COB-MS programme – a Cognitive Occupation-Based programme for people living with MS (Dwyer et al., unpublished report) – in comparison with a treatment as usual, wait-list control group (i.e. the main trial). For further details of the study within which this SWAT will be conducted (see ISRCTN11462710).

q9.value: PwMS participants will be randomly allocated to one of two study arms (i.e. PPIPIS and a SRPIS), using 1:1 allocation, via randomised block permutation (i.e. two randomised blocks of four and six per block). Randomisation will be conducted through a purpose-designed computer-generated system. Specifically, one researcher with statistical expertise will conduct the randomisation based on the sequence and type of randomisation described above. A second researcher, blind to the sequence, will collate the names of potential participants’ in light of a ‘first-come-first-serve’ basis regarding expression of interest in the study, and address information packs to potential participants based on the code yielded from the randomisation process. The code consists of a four digit, non-repeating string which cannot be ‘guessed’ by the blinded researcher. A third researcher will recode the data upon imputation, resulting in the blinding of the initial researcher, who will analyse the data.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: All individuals interested in participating will self-select through contacting the researchers by phone or email. The duration of the recruitment period for both the main trial and SWAT is eight months. Potential participants will be sent a randomly allocated PIS in the post to consider before making their decision to participate in the main trial. Participants will also be sent a consent form for the main trial and the outcome measures relevant to this SWAT. Following verbal consent via telephone, SWAT data and formal, written consent will be collected by a member of the research team, an assistant psychologist trained in psychological assessment, upon arrival to the home for the main trial’s baseline assessment (i.e. within three months of receiving their randomly allocated PIS). Consenting participants may choose not to complete some aspects or all of the self-report SWAT outcome measures and, at the same time, remain in the main trial, in which case, partial response or non-response to the self-report SWAT outcome measures will be treated as missing data. Consistent with the protocol for the main trial, those who decline to participate in the trial will be asked, with informed consent, to provide the reasons why they have declined to participate in the main trial (see Dwyer et al., Under Review ). These data will include the measures identified in this SWAT protocol. Those who consent to participate in this ‘decliner cohort’ will be asked to complete the measures already sent to them and return them completed to the research team. Those who do not consent to participate in the ‘decliner cohort’ will be thanked for their time and consideration. Rates of all forms of consent will be recorded.

q13.value: As the main trial is a feasibility study, a formal sample size calculation is not required. Instead, a pragmatic approach is adopted, based on an average recruitment rate for National Institute for Health Research (UK) funded randomised controlled trials (RCTs). One-hundred and twenty. A total of 120 PwMS will be recruited for the main trial; thus, the sample size for the SWAT will exceed 120 (i.e. accounting for ‘consent decliners’), until saturation has been reached. See Figure 1 for CONSORT flowchart of study participants.

q15.value: There is no planned interim analysis. However, statistical analysis of descriptive data may be required in consideration of stopping guidelines for cases of unforeseen circumstances. Specifically, consistent with Avery et al. (2017), transparent reporting will be made around the decision-making process for stopping, amending or proceeding with the main trial and, likewise, the SWAT. As this is a SWAT embedded within a feasibility trial, stopping rules are distinct from those seen in a definitive trial and include two types of stopping guidelines – those specific unto the SWAT and those specific unto the main trial. The latter are relevant in this context, given that stopping the main trial prematurely would block assessment of participation completion and level of retention. The stopping rule specific unto the SWAT is recruitment of less than 70% during the recruitment phase set; protocol, including data collection period not tolerated by over 25% of participants. Stopping rules for the main trial also include: drop-out rate of participants during the COB-MS intervention is great than or equal to 50%; drop-out rate of occupational therapy participants greater or equal to 40%; serious adverse event(s) reported to the data monitoring committee (DMC) that are a direct result of the COB-MS and the DMC view require the stopping of the trial.

question.value: Two PISs were developed. A standard, researcher-designed PIS (SRPIS) was written by the post-doctoral researcher – from both the SWAT and the main trial – who has over 10 years’ research experience. The researcher wrote the PIS in light of templates from past trials for structure, making sure to include/address study background, procedure, eligibility, consent, funding/support and descriptions of both potential risks and benefits. A PPI-designed-and-informed PIS (PPIPIS) was developed by a PPI member of the research team - who was neither from a research or medical background, nor had experience in these fields - who would otherwise be eligible to participate in the intervention. The PPI member wrote the PIS from a patient perspective, in light of what was deemed both necessary for potential participants to know and useful to know. The only restriction on PPIPIS development was that the PPI member was required to include/address study background, procedure, eligibility, consent, funding/support and descriptions of both potential risks and benefits. Following development of the PPIPIS, the document was further analysed, evaluated and subsequently approved as appropriate by other PPI members through discussion and agreement within a PPI focus-group; specifically: one other PPI member from the trial steering committee and an external PPI consultation group which was convened to discuss issues related to outcome measures and recruitment material, such as this. Notably, the PIS developers were blinded to each other’s PIS and did not liaise or discuss the PISs during their development, both of which were submitted separately to the primary investigator (PI) for subsequent submission for ethical approval. Both PISs were accompanied by a PI-developed addendum regarding GDPR guidelines in order to ensure consistency in this context, for ethical purposes.

Recruitment will be measured dichotomously by whether or not the PwMS consented to participate in the main trial.  

The Decisional Conflict Scale (DCS; O’Connor, 1995) is a 16 item questionnaire, answered via a five-point Likert scale, ranging from strongly agree (0) to strongly disagree (4), used to measure decision certainty, with respect to decision to provide consent to participate in this SWAT. The scale is established as valid and reliable with test–retest correlations and Cronbach's alpha of 0.78 (O’Connor, 2012). 

Retention will be measured dichotomously by whether or not the PwMS completed participation in the trial. Notably, level of retention will also be measured by stages of completion, including (0-8) COB-MS sessions completed and (1-4) testing phases completed (i.e. on a scale of 1-12).

Understanding, readability, accessibility, likeability and decision to consent will be assessed via a six-item questionnaire, developed through discussion and agreement with a PPI focus-group, to be answered via six-point Likert scale, ranging from strongly disagree (0) to strongly agree (5):  

1.	The Study Information Sheet played a large role in my decision to participate in the study. (Decision to consent) 
2.	I was able to read the information presented in the Study Information Sheet. (Understanding)
3.	I was able to understand the information presented in the Study Information Sheet. (Understanding)
4.	The language used in the Study Information Sheet was accessible to me. (Understanding)
5.	I knew I was going to consent participate before I was even presented the Study Information Sheet. (Decision to consent)
6.	Overall, I liked Study Information Sheet that was presented to me. (Likeability)
N/A

Statistical analysis will be conducted through two chi-square tests of independence, which will be performed to examine the relationship between source perspectives (i.e. PPIPIS and SRPIS) on both consent and trial completion (i.e. retention). A series of analyses of variance will be conducted to examine the effects of source perspective on level of retention, understanding, readability, accessibility, likeability, decision certainty and decision to consent regarding the two different PISs. Descriptive statistics and correlations will be reported for all measures. Sub-group analyses will be conducted if warranted by the planned analyses to aid interpretation of the statistical findings (e.g. differences between: main trial completers and non-completers; or low and high scorers on the DCS).

q21.value: Inferences will be made on p-values at the .05 level.

q23.value: Data will be treated per protocol and missing/incomplete instances will be treated as no response, except in cases of scales - that is, missing responses regarding scale items, in which case, multiple imputation will be used to replace missing data.

The researcher wrote the PIS in light of templates from past trials for structure, making sure to include/address study background, procedure, eligibility, consent, funding/support and descriptions of both potential risks and benefits. A PPI-designed-and-informed PIS (PPIPIS) was developed by a PPI member of the research team - who was neither from a research or medical background, nor had experience in these fields - who would otherwise be eligible to participate in the intervention. The PPI member wrote the PIS from a patient perspective, in light of what was deemed both necessary for potential participants to know and useful to know. The only restriction on PPIPIS development was that the PPI member was required to include/address study background, procedure, eligibility, consent, funding/support and descriptions of both potential risks and benefits. Following development of the PPIPIS, the document was further analysed, evaluated and subsequently approved as appropriate by other PPI members through discussion and agreement within a PPI focus-group; specifically: one other PPI member from the trial steering committee and an external PPI consultation group which was convened to discuss issues related to outcome measures and recruitment material, such as this. Notably, the PIS developers were blinded to each other’s PIS and did not liaise or discuss the PISs during their development, both of which were submitted separately to the primary investigator (PI) for subsequent submission for ethical approval. Both PISs were accompanied by a PI-developed addendum regarding GDPR guidelines in order to ensure consistency in this context, for ethical purposes.
registration_responses.q17.question:
Recruitment will be measured dichotomously by whether or not the PwMS consented to participate in the main trial.  

The Decisional Conflict Scale (DCS; O’Connor, 1995) is a 16 item questionnaire, answered via a five-point Likert scale, ranging from strongly agree (0) to strongly disagree (4), used to measure decision certainty, with respect to decision to provide consent to participate in this SWAT. The scale is established as valid and reliable with test–retest correlations and Cronbach's alpha of 0.78 (O’Connor, 2012). 

Retention will be measured dichotomously by whether or not the PwMS completed participation in the trial. Notably, level of retention will also be measured by stages of completion, including (0-8) COB-MS sessions completed and (1-4) testing phases completed (i.e. on a scale of 1-12).

Understanding, readability, accessibility, likeability and decision to consent will be assessed via a six-item questionnaire, developed through discussion and agreement with a PPI focus-group, to be answered via six-point Likert scale, ranging from strongly disagree (0) to strongly agree (5):  

1.	The Study Information Sheet played a large role in my decision to participate in the study. (Decision to consent) 
2.	I was able to read the information presented in the Study Information Sheet. (Understanding)
3.	I was able to understand the information presented in the Study Information Sheet. (Understanding)
4.	The language used in the Study Information Sheet was accessible to me. (Understanding)
5.	I knew I was going to consent participate before I was even presented the Study Information Sheet. (Decision to consent)
6.	Overall, I liked Study Information Sheet that was presented to me. (Likeability)
registration_responses.q18.question: N/A
registration_responses.q19.question: Statistical analysis will be conducted through two chi-square tests of independence, which will be performed to examine the relationship between source perspectives (i.e. PPIPIS and SRPIS) on both consent and trial completion (i.e. retention). A series of analyses of variance will be conducted to examine the effects of source perspective on level of retention, understanding, readability, accessibility, likeability, decision certainty and decision to consent regarding the two different PISs. Descriptive statistics and correlations will be reported for all measures. Sub-group analyses will be conducted if warranted by the planned analyses to aid interpretation of the statistical findings (e.g. differences between: main trial completers and non-completers; or low and high scorers on the DCS).

attributes.title: The impact of leadership on health and turnover

q1.value: The impact of leadership on health and turnover

q3.value: We are testing the effect of three types of supervision: Psychopathic, abusive, and exploitative on employee health, turnover intentions, and how employees are treated (e.g., LMX). We are asking primary participants (pps) and coworkers to fill out a survey about their supervisor or boss. From there, pps will be surveyed again for changes in quit intentions and overall mental health.

q4.value:
We predict the following:

psychopathic leaders will be high in both exploitative and abusive supervision

Mental health problems and quit intentions will be high among these three types of supervision

Machiavellianism will mitigate the impact of dark leadership such that individuals high in Machiavellianism will report fewer quit intentions when their job satisfaction is high, even under psychopathic supervision. 

Inconsistent ratings of a supervisor's psychopathy (e.g., the pps says s/he is not psychopathic, the coworker says s/he is) will lead to increased job satisfaction among those high in Machiavellianism

IN general, those high in the Dark Triad will see psychopathic leadership as better than those low in any Dark Triad trait.

Closeness to a psychopathic leader will increase quit intentions and mental health problems among employees.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: We are conducting a longitudinal study with two waves. The first wave will be dyadic with two coworkers rating their supervisor / boss on leadership quality, psychopathy, abusive supervision, and exploitative supervision.

attributes.title: Bidirectionality in longitudinal associations of prosocial behavior, autonomy support, and emotional support from fathers, mothers, siblings, and best friends on adolescents' prosocial behavior.
attributes.description: A six-wave longitudinal study on the associations between prosocial behavior, autonomy support, emotional support from fathers, mothers, siblings, and best friends and adolescents' prosocial behavior.

q1.value: Bidirectionality in longitudinal associations of prosocial behavior, autonomy support, and emotional support from fathers, mothers, siblings, and best friends on adolescents' prosocial behavior.

q2.value: Marije van meegen, Jolien Van der Graaff, Gustavo Carlo, Wim H. J. Meeus, Susan Branje

q3.value:
According to social learning theory, adolescents learn social behaviors by observing and mimicking others who model specific social behaviors (Bandura, 1977; Hoffman, 2008). This might imply that adolescents' prosocial behavior may be induced via parents, siblings, and best friends who model such behaviors. Adolescents' prosocial behaviors are a range of behaviors that are intended to benefit others, such as helping and sharing (Carlo, 2001;  Hastings, Utendale, & Sullivan, 2007). Close relationships provide a unique context in which reciprocity of prosocial behaviors may occur (Brown, 2004). Moreover, prosocial behavior is necessary for maintaining healthy close relationships (Padilla-Walker, Fraser, Black, & Bean, 2015), and adolescents are more prone to show prosocial behaviors towards family and friends (Amato, 1990). Even more specifically, high-quality relationships were found to be related to adolescents’ prosocial behavior (Laible, 2007; Markiewicz, Doyle, & Brendgen, 2001; Padilla-Walker & Christensen, 2011). For example, adolescents’ perception of adequate support was associated with prosocial behavior (Gagné, 2003; Laible, 2007; Nelson et al., 2015). In turn, adolescents’ prosocial behavior might also be a predictor of parent and peer relationship quality. Adolescents’prosocial behavior has been found related to the quality of friendships and affective behavior towards best friends (Markiewicz et al., 2001), and to later parenting (especially for maternal warmth) (Carlo, Mestre, Samper, Tur, & Armenta, 2011). Regarding the influence between parenting and adolescents’ prosocial behavior, this effect might be stronger between mothers and their children, then between fathers and adolescents (Hastings, McShane, Parker, & Ladha, 2007; Hastings, Utendale, William, et al., 2007). However, this theory has been substantiated with limited empirical evidence, especially concerning the reciprocal associations of parents, siblings, and best friends on adolescents’ prosocial behavior.


Moreover, most developmental studies examined associations on the between-person level. This reflects, for instance, whether adolescents who perceive more support become more prosocial than other adolescents but does not necessarily reflect whether adolescents become more prosocial than before when they perceive more support than before. From a transactional perspective, it would be more logical to assess the reciprocity within dyads, such as dynamic processes between autonomy support, emotional support, and prosocial behavior within dyads. Therefore, it is necessary to separate the between-dyad variance from the within-dyad variance to gain an understanding of how these constructs are linked to adolescents' prosocial behavior (Hamaker, Kuiper, & Grasman, 2015).

q4.value:
Primary hypotheses on the within-level. 
1.	Within dyads, we expect bidirectional associations between increased adolescents’ prosocial behavior and increased prosocial behavior from fathers, mothers, siblings, or best friends, both concurrently and longitudinally across 1-year intervals.
2.	Within dyads, we expect bidirectional associations between increased perceived autonomy and emotional support from fathers, mothers, siblings, and best friends and increased adolescents’ prosocial behavior, both concurrently and longitudinally across 1-year intervals. We expect this link to be stronger for mother-adolescent dyads than for father-adolescent dyads. 

Primary hypotheses on the between-level. 
3.	Adolescents who perceive more autonomy support and emotional support from fathers, mothers, siblings, and best friends become more prosocial compared to other adolescents who perceive less autonomy support and emotional support. We expect to find this link both concurrently and longitudinally across 1-year intervals.
4.	 Adolescents who perceive less autonomy support and emotional support from fathers, mothers, siblings, and best friends become less prosocial compared to other adolescents who perceive more autonomy support and emotional support. We expect to find this link both concurrently and longitudinally across 1-year intervals.
5.	Adolescents become more prosocial when their fathers, mothers, siblings, and best friends display more prosocial behavior compared to other adolescents whose fathers, mothers, siblings, and best friends display less prosocial behavior. We expect to find this link both concurrently and longitudinally across 1-year intervals.
6.	Adolescents become less prosocial when their fathers, mothers, siblings. and best friends display less prosocial behavior compared to other adolescents whose fathers, mothers, siblings, and best friends display more prosocial behavior. We expect to find this link both concurrently and longitudinally across 1-year intervals.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This study is part of the larger longitudinal study (i.e., RADAR-young) (Branje & Meeus, 2018). In total, 497 adolescents, both parents, a sibling, and adolescents' best friend, were included in the study. We used 6 waves of annual survey data.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: We will use the first six waves from the ongoing RADAR young research project (Branje & Meeus, 2018) in order to answer our research questions. The first wave was collected in 2006, when adolescents were 13 years old. To receive the data, the first author had to write a data request. This request had to be approved by the Principal Investigators (Susan Branje and Wim Meeus). The co-authors (van der Graaff et al., 2015) presented part of these data during a presentation at the 17th European Conference on Developmental Psychology (2015) and the conference of the Society for Research on Child Development (SRCD; 2015), but findings were not published in an academic journal. The presented findings at SRCD were based on only part of the variables of the current study and on analyses on the between-person level, in contrast to the proposed hypotheses of the current study. Also, none of these findings were shared with the first author, who proposed the hypotheses and will be responsible for the statistical analyses of the current study. Lastly, pre-registration is done before exploring or analyzing the data.

question.value: This study is part of the larger longitudinal study (i.e., RADAR-young). The RADAR-young study has been approved by the Medical Ethical Committee of Utrecht University Medical Centre and was conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki. Approximately 429 schools were randomly selected from 850 elementary schools in Utrecht, Rotterdam, The Hague, and Almere. Of these schools, 296 were willing to participate, due to logistic reasons 230 schools were included in the study. This resulted in 1544 adolescents, of which 364 adolescents were excluded because their siblings were ≥10 years of age, or both parents were not present. In addition, phone records were incorrect or missing, and therefore, 99 adolescents were excluded, 470 adolescents refused to participate in the study, and 114 families did not provide consent for all study members. This resulted in 497 adolescents, their parents, sibling, and their best friend. All participants signed informed consent before they were visited by a trained research assistant. During these home visits, all participants filled out a battery of questionnaires for which participants received 20 euros.

q13.value: Our sample consists of N=497 adolescents, their fathers, mothers, siblings, and best friends.

q14.value: The RADAR-study aimed to include roughly 500 families consisting of adolescents, both parents, one sibling, and the adolescent's best friend. The involvement of these participants is important because RADAR focuses on adolescents' development, considering the relationships with parents, siblings, and best friends. Due to the intensive data collection, participants were required to understand the Dutch language. Taken together, this resulted in 497 participants.

question.value: N/A

Prosocial behavior. Adolescents, parents, siblings, and best friends reported on their own prosocial with the Dutch version of the 11-item subscale “prosocial behavior” from the Self-report of Aggression and Social Behavior Measure (Morales & Crick 1998; Linder, crick, & Collins, 2002). The items were rated on a 7-point Likert scale ranging from 1 to (not at all true) to 7 (very true). A sample item is: “I'm willing to help others."

Autonomy support. Adolescents reported on perceived autonomy support from parents, siblings, and best friends with the 7-item subscale "balanced relatedness" of the Dutch version of Adolescent Intimacy Revisited (Shulman, Laursen, Kalman, & Karpovsky, 1997). The items were rated on a 4-point scale ranging from 1(strongly disagree) to 4 (strongly agree). An example item is: “My best friend respects my ideas.”

Emotional Support. Adolescents reported on perceived emotional support from parents, siblings, and best friends with the Dutch version of the 8-item subscale “support” from the Network of Relationships Inventory (Furman & Buhrmester, 1985). The items were rated on a 5-point scale ranging from 1 (little or no) to 7 (more is not possible). A sample item is: “How much does your best friend care about you?”.

We will calculate mean scores for each variable based on all items per (sub-)scale.

Predictors and outcomes: 
Autonomy support from parents, siblings and best friends. 
Emotional support from parents, siblings and best friends.
Self-reported prosocial behavior from adolescents, parents, siblings and best friends.

At first, data screening procedures will be performed. To test the pattern of missing data, Little's Missing Completely At Random (MCAR) test will be applied in SPSS, this will be indicated by ≥ α .05. We will use Full Information Maximum Likelihood (FIML) in the main analyses if there is any missing data. Furthermore, we will check normality, skewness, and kurtosis if the values of skewness and kurtosis for the outcome variable are smaller than 2 times its standard error than there is no indication that the data is not highly skewed. If the data meet the assumptions, then Maximum Likelihood estimation will be used. Otherwise, Maximum Likelihood with Robust standard errors will be used. We will calculate descriptive statistics and (intraclass) correlations. 	

The intraclass correlation (ICC) will be calculated in order to investigate whether there is variance on the between-dyads level and the within-dyads level. Here, the ICC will indicate whether the variance is due to between-dyads differences and not due to fluctuations over-time within dyads. It is preferable to use random intercept cross-lagged panel model (RI-CLPM), when we find an intra-class correlation of ≥ .10 (Kline, 2011; Maas & Hox, 2005). In order to test our hypotheses, we will use a random intercept cross-lagged panel model (RI-CLPM) which separates the observed score on a within-person level from between-person levels of our variables of interest. This is achieved by adding a random intercept for all the variables: prosocial behavior, autonomy support, and emotional support. In total 4 models will be examined, a model per support provider, viz: 1) adolescents perception on autonomy support from mothers, adolescents perception on emotional support from mothers, mother-reported prosocial behavior and adolescent-reported prosocial behavior; 2) adolescents perception on autonomy support from fathers, adolescents perception on emotional support from fathers, father-reported prosocial behavior and adolescent-reported prosocial behavior; 3) adolescents perception on autonomy support from siblings, adolescents perception on emotional support from siblings, sibling-reported prosocial behavior and adolescent-reported prosocial behavior; 4) adolescents perception on autonomy support from best friends, adolescents perception on emotional support from best friends, best friend-reported prosocial behavior and adolescent-reported prosocial behavior. The following steps will be applied to each model.

First, a model with fully constrained autoregressive effects and cross-lagged effects is compared to a model with freely estimated autoregressive effects and cross-lagged effects, in order to test whether the factor structure is time-invariant. Then we will compare the model with the fit indices described below. In multigroup analyses, parameters will be constrained for males and females to assess the moderating effect of gender (Hamaker, 2018). Next, the significant associations will be combined in a final model in order to examine the reciprocal links from mothers, fathers, siblings, and best friends on adolescent's prosocial behavior. We will apply a sensitive test to the final model, where we will run the model with only complete cases. All main analyses will be computed in Mplus version 8.

q21.value: To determine whether the effects of the proposed models are significant, α = .05 will be used. Moreover, to assess model fit, we will use Root Mean-Square Error of Approximation ≤.08, Comparative Fit Index ≥ .90, Tucker-Lewis Index ≥.90 (Pituch & Stevens, 2016).

q23.value: If there is missing data, we will use Full Information Maximum Likelihood (FIML) in the main analyses.

We expect to find this link both concurrently and longitudinally across 1-year intervals.
4.	 Adolescents who perceive less autonomy support and emotional support from fathers, mothers, siblings, and best friends become less prosocial compared to other adolescents who perceive more autonomy support and emotional support. We expect to find this link both concurrently and longitudinally across 1-year intervals.
5.	Adolescents become more prosocial when their fathers, mothers, siblings, and best friends display more prosocial behavior compared to other adolescents whose fathers, mothers, siblings, and best friends display less prosocial behavior. We expect to find this link both concurrently and longitudinally across 1-year intervals.
6.	Adolescents become less prosocial when their fathers, mothers, siblings. and best friends display less prosocial behavior compared to other adolescents whose fathers, mothers, siblings, and best friends display more prosocial behavior. We expect to find this link both concurrently and longitudinally across 1-year intervals.
registration_responses.q5: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to analysis of the data
registration_responses.q11: We will use the first six waves from the ongoing RADAR young research project (Branje & Meeus, 2018) in order to answer our research questions. The first wave was collected in 2006, when adolescents were 13 years old. To receive the data, the first author had to write a data request. This request had to be approved by the Principal Investigators (Susan Branje and Wim Meeus). The co-authors (van der Graaff et al., 2015) presented part of these data during a presentation at the 17th European Conference on Developmental Psychology (2015) and the conference of the Society for Research on Child Development (SRCD; 2015), but findings were not published in an academic journal. The presented findings at SRCD were based on only part of the variables of the current study and on analyses on the between-person level, in contrast to the proposed hypotheses of the current study. Also, none of these findings were shared with the first author, who proposed the hypotheses and will be responsible for the statistical analyses of the current study. Lastly, pre-registration is done before exploring or analyzing the data.
registration_responses.q13: Our sample consists of N=497 adolescents, their fathers, mothers, siblings, and best friends.
registration_responses.q14: The RADAR-study aimed to include roughly 500 families consisting of adolescents, both parents, one sibling, and the adolescent's best friend. The involvement of these participants is important because RADAR focuses on adolescents' development, considering the relationships with parents, siblings, and best friends. Due to the intensive data collection, participants were required to understand the Dutch language. Taken together, this resulted in 497 participants.
registration_responses.q21: To determine whether the effects of the proposed models are significant, α = .05 will be used. Moreover, to assess model fit, we will use Root Mean-Square Error of Approximation ≤.08, Comparative Fit Index ≥ .90, Tucker-Lewis Index ≥.90 (Pituch & Stevens, 2016).
registration_responses.q23: If there is missing data, we will use Full Information Maximum Likelihood (FIML) in the main analyses.

registration_responses.q8.question: This study is part of the larger longitudinal study (i.e., RADAR-young) (Branje & Meeus, 2018). In total, 497 adolescents, both parents, a sibling, and adolescents' best friend, were included in the study. We used 6 waves of annual survey data.
registration_responses.q12.question: This study is part of the larger longitudinal study (i.e., RADAR-young). The RADAR-young study has been approved by the Medical Ethical Committee of Utrecht University Medical Centre and was conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki. Approximately 429 schools were randomly selected from 850 elementary schools in Utrecht, Rotterdam, The Hague, and Almere. Of these schools, 296 were willing to participate, due to logistic reasons 230 schools were included in the study. This resulted in 1544 adolescents, of which 364 adolescents were excluded because their siblings were ≥10 years of age, or both parents were not present. In addition, phone records were incorrect or missing, and therefore, 99 adolescents were excluded, 470 adolescents refused to participate in the study, and 114 families did not provide consent for all study members. This resulted in 497 adolescents, their parents, sibling, and their best friend. All participants signed informed consent before they were visited by a trained research assistant. During these home visits, all participants filled out a battery of questionnaires for which participants received 20 euros.

registration_responses.q17.question:
Prosocial behavior. Adolescents, parents, siblings, and best friends reported on their own prosocial with the Dutch version of the 11-item subscale “prosocial behavior” from the Self-report of Aggression and Social Behavior Measure (Morales & Crick 1998; Linder, crick, & Collins, 2002). The items were rated on a 7-point Likert scale ranging from 1 to (not at all true) to 7 (very true). A sample item is: “I'm willing to help others."

Autonomy support. Adolescents reported on perceived autonomy support from parents, siblings, and best friends with the 7-item subscale "balanced relatedness" of the Dutch version of Adolescent Intimacy Revisited (Shulman, Laursen, Kalman, & Karpovsky, 1997). The items were rated on a 4-point scale ranging from 1(strongly disagree) to 4 (strongly agree). An example item is: “My best friend respects my ideas.”

Emotional Support. Adolescents reported on perceived emotional support from parents, siblings, and best friends with the Dutch version of the 8-item subscale “support” from the Network of Relationships Inventory (Furman & Buhrmester, 1985). The items were rated on a 5-point scale ranging from 1 (little or no) to 7 (more is not possible). A sample item is: “How much does your best friend care about you?”.

We will calculate mean scores for each variable based on all items per (sub-)scale.
registration_responses.q19.question:
Predictors and outcomes: 
Autonomy support from parents, siblings and best friends. 
Emotional support from parents, siblings and best friends.
Self-reported prosocial behavior from adolescents, parents, siblings and best friends.

At first, data screening procedures will be performed. To test the pattern of missing data, Little's Missing Completely At Random (MCAR) test will be applied in SPSS, this will be indicated by ≥ α .05. We will use Full Information Maximum Likelihood (FIML) in the main analyses if there is any missing data. Furthermore, we will check normality, skewness, and kurtosis if the values of skewness and kurtosis for the outcome variable are smaller than 2 times its standard error than there is no indication that the data is not highly skewed. If the data meet the assumptions, then Maximum Likelihood estimation will be used. Otherwise, Maximum Likelihood with Robust standard errors will be used. We will calculate descriptive statistics and (intraclass) correlations. 	

The intraclass correlation (ICC) will be calculated in order to investigate whether there is variance on the between-dyads level and the within-dyads level. Here, the ICC will indicate whether the variance is due to between-dyads differences and not due to fluctuations over-time within dyads. It is preferable to use random intercept cross-lagged panel model (RI-CLPM), when we find an intra-class correlation of ≥ .10 (Kline, 2011; Maas & Hox, 2005). In order to test our hypotheses, we will use a random intercept cross-lagged panel model (RI-CLPM) which separates the observed score on a within-person level from between-person levels of our variables of interest. This is achieved by adding a random intercept for all the variables: prosocial behavior, autonomy support, and emotional support. In total 4 models will be examined, a model per support provider, viz: 1) adolescents perception on autonomy support from mothers, adolescents perception on emotional support from mothers, mother-reported prosocial behavior and adolescent-reported prosocial behavior; 2) adolescents perception on autonomy support from fathers, adolescents perception on emotional support from fathers, father-reported prosocial behavior and adolescent-reported prosocial behavior; 3) adolescents perception on autonomy support from siblings, adolescents perception on emotional support from siblings, sibling-reported prosocial behavior and adolescent-reported prosocial behavior; 4) adolescents perception on autonomy support from best friends, adolescents perception on emotional support from best friends, best friend-reported prosocial behavior and adolescent-reported prosocial behavior. The following steps will be applied to each model.

First, a model with fully constrained autoregressive effects and cross-lagged effects is compared to a model with freely estimated autoregressive effects and cross-lagged effects, in order to test whether the factor structure is time-invariant. Then we will compare the model with the fit indices described below. In multigroup analyses, parameters will be constrained for males and females to assess the moderating effect of gender (Hamaker, 2018). Next, the significant associations will be combined in a final model in order to examine the reciprocal links from mothers, fathers, siblings, and best friends on adolescent's prosocial behavior. We will apply a sensitive test to the final model, where we will run the model with only complete cases. All main analyses will be computed in Mplus version 8.
